oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Johnny Lee Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Johnny Lee (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Johnny Lee; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Johnny Lee radio spot addressing his album New Directions and the Music City Album Review -- (00:13) Lee radio spot addressing his triple-platinum record; additionally, Lee addresses his album New Directions and the Music City Album Review -- (00:39) Lee addresses Biff Collie while introducing the commercial break as a disc jockey in a radio spot -- (00:50) Lee addresses the listeners when doing a Music City Album Review radio spot -- (01:00) Lee laughs and says, 'I love it' -- (01:05) Lee radio spot addresses the New Directions album -- (01:19) Lee radio spot predicting his album will bring Lee success -- (01:41) Lee radio spot addressing Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (01:52) Lee radio spot telling the audience to visit their local library to find his book as Collie laughs in the background -- (02:08) Lee reflects on being born in Texas City, Texas; as well as, his grandmother influencing his name after Johnnie Lee Wills -- (02:20) Lee addresses working on a dairy farm and how Santa Fe had changed its name -- (02:45) Lee recalls his first show, being a talent show, was sponsored by the Future Farmers of America -- (03:11) Collie and Lee reflect on the meaning of the name New Directions and how Lee had changed producers and recording companies -- (03:57) "You Can't Fly Like an Eagle" is discussed by Collie and Lee as a track with a huge message and Lee describes the emotional impact of the song -- (05:27) Lee reflects on the first time he heard "Cardboard Mansion" -- (05:49) Lee's first reaction to "I Can Be a Heartbreaker Too" led him to think that it was a song that expressed a rare message -- (06:42) Lee and Collie talk about the reason they named the album New Directions was because of the variation in song styles -- (08:18) "Cross My Heart" is described as a 'Johnny Lee Two-step' about love by Lee -- (09:07) Lee reflects on working on "Maybe I Won't Love You Anymore" when writer Gene Thomas had it snuck into the demo tapes -- (10:23) Lee reflects on his favorite line out of "Maybe I Won't Love You Anymore" -- (10:41) Collie and Lee discuss how Lee would frequent Gilley's and how "Looking for Love" gave him an opportunity to perform for a movie -- (12:31) Lee recalls working in a room filled with tapes, discovering "Looking for Love," and how the song came from a group of second-grade children -- (14:10) Collie brings up "The Anniversary Song" and Lee describes it as a song about his love for his wife -- (15:10) Lee recalls a time a man in the army sent him a post-card about "The Anniversary Song" -- (15:44) Lee describes the act of recording "Heart to Heart Talk" -- (16:43) Lee and Collie discuss seeing the Cornelius Brothers and Sister Rose live -- (16:57) Lee describes the feeling he had for "Treat Her Like a Lady" and Collie and Lee converse about how working at a club influenced Lee's variety -- (18:21) Lee and Collie discuss Sam Neely's contribution on "I'm Not Over You" -- (20:05) "By-Pass Row" is discussed by Lee and Collie as a real place that has a lot of backing from the fans and Lee's producer -- (22:00) Lee describes how his grandmother used to listen to Collie, and Collie and Lee reflect on how "Chew Tobacco Rag" was Lee's first song -- (22:52) Collie reveals to Lee that he is about to play "Chew Tobacco Rag" -- (23:08) Lee introduces the song "Chew Tobacco Rag" and reveals how it is the first time he had done so -- (23:28) "Anni" is revealed by Lee to be the first song he ever wrote to be produced by a large recording company -- (23:59) Lee reflects on working at the Palomino Club, where he met Anni, and how he tried to get Anni to record with him -- (26:29) Lee reflects on the Music City Album Review show -- (26:47) Lee asks Collie to remind the listeners about his book
